Situation1: A minor misunderstanding about weekend plans just arose.
Situation2: They manage high-value transactions at the end of a shift, where mistakes could cause significant financial discrepancies.
Story: The register beeped insistently as I scanned the last few items, my mind racing with the text I’d just read from Alex. “I thought we were going to your parents’ this weekend?” he’d written, the words sharp with disappointment. I could feel the tension in my chest, the urge to call him and smooth things over, to explain that I’d misunderstood, that I wanted to fix it. But the line at my register was long, and the drawer was full of large bills—end-of-shift, high-stakes counting. My manager expected perfection, no errors, especially now. I tried to focus on the numbers, but Alex’s message echoed in my head, guilt mixing with anxiety. I wanted to be the girlfriend who resolved things right away, who didn’t let misunderstandings fester. But I also needed to be the cashier who didn’t make mistakes, who didn’t let personal drama interfere with work. My hands trembled as I handed back change, torn between the urge to grab my phone and the responsibility to finish my shift without error.
